sentence.text: An 8-y-old boy, who was the second child of non consanguineous parents, was referred for evaluation of short stature noticed since 5 y of age.
He was normal at birth except for sparse hair.
He had normal development and his scholastic performance was good.
He did not have any symptoms of immunodeficiency and malabsorption.
His parents were of normal height.

On clinical examination, his weight was 20.7 kg (3rd centile for age), height 99 cm (less than 3rd centile for age), upper segment (US): lower segment (LS) ratio 1.2:1 (infantile), and arm span 109 cm which was greater than his height.
He also had a mild scoliosis to left and brachydactyly with 5th digit clinodactyly, bilaterally.
He had sparse and light colored hair, eyebrows and eyelashes.
His blood counts, serum alkaline phosphatase (215 U/dl) and immunoglobulin profile were normal (IgG 1660 mg/dl, IgE 343 IU/ml, IgM 81.2 mg/dl and Ig A 303 mg/dl).

His radiographs revealed, widened metaphysis with irregularities and brachydactyly (Fig. 1) As the features were suggestive of cartilage hair hypoplasia, sequencing of RMRP gene was done and a homozygous g. 70 A > G mutation was identified.
